awd_titl_txt: EAGER: G4-TIRFM, a platform for massively parallel analysis of non-canonical DNA structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Not all DNA has the familiar double-helix shape. Some regions of DNA rich in one of the four building blocks, guanine, form a different, four stranded kind of structure, called G-quadruplex (G4). Th the human genome, there are more than 700,000 G4-forming regions, and about 10,000 of them were shown to form G4s in cells. Some G4s interfere with DNA replication, DNA repair and RNA transcription. This project will combine the state of the art DNA sequencing technology with fluorescent microscopy to attach all G4 regions in human genome to the solid sorface and study their interactions with other molecules. The project will provide research experience for the undergraduates and high school students recruited through several outreach mechanisms at the University of Iowa.


G-quadruplexes play important roles in regulating DNA replication, DNA repair and RNA transcription. This project will provide a technology platform for the parallel analysis and comparison of thousands of potential structures that can form within the G-rich sequences. Human G4 chromatin will be immunoprecipitated using specific antibodies and sequenced using an Illumina MiSeq next generation sequencing flow cells. Instead of disposing the flow cell after sequencing, it will be employed in a non-conventional way: ssDNA that has been clonally amplifed in the sequencing process will be allowed to refold into G4 structures, and modified TIRF microscope will be used to visualize and quantify clusters of folded G4 DNA. Visualization of G4 will be repeated after treatments with DNA polymerases, polymerase/helicase combinations and other G4 binders. To increase the diversity in and excitement about STEM research, the team will continue their involvement with the institutional outreach programs to provide research opportunities to undergraduate and high school students, as well as faculty and students from Iowa undergraduate institutions that do not offer doctoral programs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this EArly Grants for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project was to develop G4-TIRFM, a transformative, technically innovative experimental platform that brings together genomics and visualization of individual protein-DNA interactions at the level of individual sequences. Here we have built a new bespoke microscopy system that allows us to visualize DNA sequencing chips and carry out biochemical experiments on thousands distinct sequences in parallel. Our proof-of-principle experiments reveled broad sequence/structure selectivity of the human PARP1 enzyme. The outcomes of this work will enable direct visualization of how the molecular machines of the cell navigate difficult DNA sequences.

The analysis we carried out involved specific DNA sequences, rich in guanines, that can form nonstandard structures called G-quadraplexes, or G4s. Some of the potential 700,000 G4 structures in human genome play important physiological functions, others function pathologically. Our experimental system will help to explain how these structures, with highly diverse folds are recognized, and how they evolved alongside molecular machines that recognize and process them.  

The second important outcome of this work is the development of a new G4-recognition protein that can become a useful reagent in single-molecule, biochemical, structural and cellular studies. This new protein binds to a broad range of G- quadraplexes with distinct structural folds, while being selective for G4 DNA over other DNA structures.
